thread_text:
1188795948375232513 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 💜 6
Perhaps I should start a thread of ideas for Twitter power-tools. Who needs note-taking applications when you've got Twitter threads?
↓
1188796528959217667 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 
- Searching within your own "likes".

- A search filter for polls.

https://t.co/bJtHJmloC1
  [Quoting @easoncxz: Also, Twitter search is really being stretched to breaking point here: not only have I no way to search my favourited tweets (aka "likes"), there's also nothing to find polls, in the style of a `filter:polls` search term. https://t.co/7Yj8rzv5L8]
↓
1188796905502851072 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 
- Usable UI for all "advanced search" terms/clauses

https://t.co/oMaDVz98j0
  [Quoting @easoncxz: The `filter:follows` operator mentioned in the earliest tweet in this thread is mentioned also in this Twitter search guide: https://t.co/ckgJiGJYsc  Interestingly, I have trouble finding this `filter:follows` clause in any official Twitter docs.]
↓
1188797325616959488 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 💜 1
- Timeline/List replay tool (ideally with usable scrubbing UI). This one is big for archaeology of historic events (aka news) on Twitter.

https://t.co/ll1pSbCcBk
  [Quoting @easoncxz: This is actually so incredibly fascinating: we can also see the opposing camp's perspective by finding a list of pro-China accounts, and rewind the timeline there. E.g. this horrible list: https://t.co/Z1uMUpJ5M9  Yields these HKIA videos: https://t.co/LpaRtB6jKw]
↓
1188799353688748037 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 
A social network structure analysis tool, e.g. "find my biggest followers". Since we're aiming for "power tool", at max ambition, this could conceivably have SQL (!!) as its UI. Of course, alternatively, a click-through UI for common queries would also be nice.
↓
1188799877892820993 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 💜 2
As always, @visakanv emits and attracts various Twitter skills; I've just stumbled upon this reference to a Twitter CLI power tool: https://t.co/Khm2QQJWjd
  [Quoting Tweet 1050006798034526208 (missing)]
↓
1188803375036424193 [2019-10-28] @easoncxz 💜 1
@visakanv Next idea: something that deals with the tree-ness of Twitter threads (we're lucky due to one tweet having only one in-reply-to tweet, we have a tree instead of a general graph). Relevant discussion: https://t.co/EaNrhofQq6

The solution could be a Reddit-like UI (!!) for Tweets.
  [Quoting @Malcolm_Ocean: @GRITCULT For linear threads: @threadreaderapp. @kriskarzy For branchy conversations: Treeverse https://t.co/fX76jMpXuP  I want an app that lets you send tweets in-thread while browsing tree-wise, and would contribute $200-500 towards someone making it. RT if also interested. https://t.co/0hcfmoZnez]
↓
1188975929361649665 [2019-10-29] @easoncxz 
@visakanv Oh yeah, almost missed this obvious one (which was once upon a time provided by Twitter as an official feature): see a given user's timeline (i.e. of accounts they follow). https://t.co/WYEvehCXMf
  [Quoting Tweet 1152321460079403008 (missing)]
↓
1197664353924739072 [2019-11-21] @easoncxz 💜 2
@visakanv A super-condensed structural metadata visualisation tool, like Tetris: https://t.co/WN8nslIu3G
↓
1273256521162317830 [2020-06-17] @easoncxz 
"You and X both blocked these 283 accounts: …" and "X is blocked by 125 accounts you follow". https://t.co/mFIQeA8nJD

As it stands, this may not be possible because personal blocklists are not public, but there are (or had been! 😢) efforts like https://t.co/MWPLOLQvkb
  [Quoting Tweet 1273186185083576322 (missing)]
↓
1322118276617363458 [2020-10-30] @easoncxz 💜 1 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
Personal-assistant for thread-composition: https://t.co/OVYOrGYXLK
  [Quoting @nosilverv: GOOD NEWS EVERYONE!  ThreadHelper is now available!   You can go get it at https://t.co/vI0KWAfUny  Here is what it looks like and what it does:  https://t.co/etHq4r5sXc]
↓
1385018216351617024 [2021-04-21] @easoncxz 
Tweet calendar: a catalogue of tweets of one user (let's say yourself) organised by date units (week, month etc) https://t.co/dfGBkMxZD9

===

Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a collage of religious artwork, with a prominent logo in the center. The logo features the text "Thread Helper" in a white box on a dark blue background, with "Thread" written in a stylized font and "Helper" in a more straightforward font.
    
    *   The top half of the image depicts a scene of Jesus Christ surrounded by angels and saints, all with halos, against a starry night sky.
        *   Jesus is shown in a circular frame, wearing an orange robe and gesturing outward with both hands.
        *   The surrounding figures are seated on benches, dressed in various robes, and appear to be watching Jesus.
    *   The bottom half of the image is divided into three sections, each depicting a different biblical scene.
        *   The left section shows a group of people gathered around a figure, possibly a baptism or other religious ritual.
        *   The middle section features a person standing on a cliff, looking out over a body of water, with a figure in the distance.
        *   The right section illustrates a dramatic scene of people being swept away by a large wave or flood, with a dragon-like creature in the foreground.
    *   The overall atmosphere of the image is one of reverence and spirituality, with the religious artwork and logo suggesting a connection to a particular faith or community.
    
    The image appears to be promoting a service or tool related to online discussions or forums, possibly focused on religious or spiritual topics.

1318477990884499458 [2020-10-20] @nosilverv 💜 2
@JimmyRis @ExGenesis I have been summoned 

(March 2020) https://t.co/9HDOAZmNQc
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a document discussing Twitter threading, with the following content:
    
    The document is titled "About me:" and has two main sections: "The Why" and "Opportunity". 
    
    "The Why" section discusses how problem-solving is bottlenecked by cognitive innovation, which comes from applying new perspectives to existing problems or creating new ones. It proposes an app to speed up the creation of unique worldviews via Twitter.
    
    The section lists three points to understand the opportunity:
    1. Twitter threading is popular and powerful
    2. Twitter threading is hard
    3. The contemporary Twitter trend of "atmaxxing"
    
    The "Opportunity" section expands on the first point, stating that Twitter threading is popular and powerful, and provides examples of its effectiveness. 
    
    The text is written in black font on a white background, with some words highlighted in red or blue.
↓

@nosilverv @ExGenesis This strikes me as a document that was generated after you had already been inspired to build it
↓
1318594214477791232 [2020-10-20] @JimmyRis 
@nosilverv @ExGenesis True?

↓

1321517532910653440 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 105 🔁 14 💬 3
A THREADHELPER 🧵FROM @nosilverv & @ExGenesis TH right now is a humble intervention on the Twitter experience.At a human level, it saves you search time and surprises you with relevant tweetsAt a system level, it redirects the flow of attention to IRRIGATE THE PAST.🧵1/17

===

1321517549520080903 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 19 🔁 1
The duration of your content's life is extended, it becomes viable to spend more effort on posts because we no longer expect them to be ephemeral as we get frictionless access to past insights.https://t.co/gPi3PB5qi9🧵7/17
  [Quoting @visakanv: The race is on to assemble the best possible articulations of ideas in ways that are not just funny or clever, but deeply resonant in ways that make other people want to revisit and reuse them repeatedly  broke: viral tweet  woke: tweet that’s referenced & reused in many threads]
↓
1321517556486885378 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 19
As you do this, so will others. From a fertile ecosystem, desire paths emerge around the threads most traveled. Around those paths, "mindcities", scenes, new forks pop up.https://t.co/oPWqMzAhgz🧵8/17 https://t.co/hEUgODcBgp
  [Quoting @visakanv: Now that more of us are playing the threading game:  As we compete+collaborate effectively articulate things we all care about,  And weave each other’s thoughts into our respective webs,  The desire paths will assemble a mindcity paved with the best individual thoughts]
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image depicts a man walking on a dirt path in a park, with the words "User experience" and "Design" superimposed over the image.
    
    *   The man is walking away from the camera, carrying a red bag in his right hand.
        *   He is wearing dark clothing and has short hair.
        *   The dirt path he is on is surrounded by grass and trees.
    *   The word "User experience" is written in black text on a white rectangle, positioned near the center of the image.
        *   It is placed over the dirt path that the man is walking on.
    *   The word "Design" is written in black text on a white rectangle, positioned near the bottom-right corner of the image.
        *   It is placed over a paved path that runs parallel to the dirt path.
    *   In the background, there are several buildings, including a large brick building with many windows.
        *   There are also several benches and streetlights throughout the park.
    *   The overall atmosphere of the image suggests a peaceful and serene environment, with the man enjoying a leisurely walk in the park.
    
    The image appears to be illustrating the concept of "desire paths," which are informal paths that people create by walking through a space in a way that deviates from the intended design. The image suggests that the user's experience (the dirt path) can diverge from the intended design (the paved path), highlighting the importance of considering user behavior when designing public spaces.
↓
1321517559833911296 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 14
Our plan is to become a "needle-shaped vessel",  a THREAD-SPACE-SHIP. Perceive and navigate this massive tapestry while interweaving your own threads into the mesh. 🧵9/17
↓
1321517563311017985 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 17
You'll be able to open full threads on the sidebar, with a tab interface that lets you shift click a tweet or QT to fork and see its thread. Also, you'll get a bird's eye view of threads you have open and how they intersect on a graph.(mockup)https://t.co/4UPAp2xtyN🧵10/17 https://t.co/gP5X3hkENX
  [Quoting @visakanv: thanks to @ollybot_browne I finally have a visual on what the @visakanv web of threads looks like  https://t.co/t9KJvZ1bG4 https://t.co/7haf0S5zDJ]
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a screenshot of a user interface design for a Twitter feature called "ThreadHelper." 
    
    The image shows a dark blue interface with the title "ThreadHelper" in white text at the top left, accompanied by a green dot. To the right of the title is a gear icon and the text "(load archive)" in gray. Below the title are three icons: a curved arrow, a bookmark, and a heart. On the right side of the image, a graph displays a thread of tweets, with lines connecting the tweets to show their relationships. The background of the image is dark blue, providing a clean and simple visual representation of the ThreadHelper feature.
↓
1321517565433315333 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 15
Less of a neat workspace, more a chaos-powered dashboard. Harness Twitter's dopamine mill and channel it into a massively collaborative ecosystem. Illegible wilderness becomes navigable-but-in-flux paths and structures.https://t.co/IhV6JUr8kN🧵11/17
  [Quoting @visakanv: Twitter is the fucking coolest note-taking app. It’s like Evernote with a slot machine attached.  Sometimes you get incredible feedback or a response that gives you 10x more value than you expected, and sometimes you get people discussing your genitalia! So exciting https://t.co/GzFu6ErvXH]
↓
1321517567421353984 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 13
Like Roam, but multiplayer-first.https://t.co/KnL2DOtln0🧵12/17
  [Quoting Tweet 1247316304006008832 (missing)]
↓
1321517569510092800 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 14
A bit farther into the future, we expect to be able to pull and search content from anywhere, basically a second-brain, allowing you to "search yourself".https://t.co/xb18Ey1ZzR🧵13/17
  [Quoting @JimmyRis: @SupaMalaman @ExGenesis is threadhelper a solution to this pretty gnarly “can’t search myself” issue?]
↓
1321517571535998976 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 23 🔁 4 💬 1
If you get tired BIG COMPANY TM, we intend on eventually adopting a user-centric peer-to-peer architecture a la HolochainYour data goes from split btw different companies to associated with you and is merely read by services and other people. https://t.co/3oMWHVE0lE🧵14/17
  [Quoting Tweet 1272945313725026306 (missing)]
↓
1321517573536686081 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 13
It matters to us that people remain sovereign and in control of their data. We'll help you store your data without compromising privacy.By gathering data from different sources and letting people access and post it, a new context is born from the use that's made of TH. 🧵15/17
↓
1321517575193399296 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 14 🔁 1
We have a vision for a fairer, more human-centric web. This is just an example but recommendation algorithms are often exploitative. A market for modular, open-source recommendation algorithms that you can switch between at will incentivizes fair play in what  gets shown🧵16/17
↓
1321517577059897344 [2020-10-28] @exgenesis 💜 28 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
Eventually, ThreadHelper becomes a full-fledged vessel to surf and participate in the information web. The future is uncertain but having a trajectory feels right.ThreadHelper open alpha starts today. Have fun!🧵17/17
↓

1321518942033186822 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 247 🔁 39 💬 19 [(SEED) type=root]
GOOD NEWS EVERYONE!

ThreadHelper is now available! 

You can go get it at https://t.co/vI0KWAfUny

Here is what it looks like and what it does:

https://t.co/etHq4r5sXc
├── 1321518943631278088 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 25 🔁 1
│   Why ThreadHelper? 
│   
│   Read this thread by @ExGenesis 
│   
│   https://t.co/wqkutUzLcd
│     [Quoting @exgenesis: A THREADHELPER 🧵FROM @nosilverv & @ExGenesis TH right now is a humble intervention on the Twitter experience.At a human level, it saves you search time and surprises you with relevant tweetsAt a system level, it redirects the flow of attention to IRRIGATE THE PAST.🧵1/17]
│   ↓
│   1321518945229246464 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 33
│   You're back? Great. Time for some acknowledgments.
│   
│   Firstly to @tylercowen, whose Emergent Ventures grant got us started. Thank you.
│   ↓
│   1321518951441014785 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 16
│   In truth, there are many people to thank for ThreadHelper being what it is today. 
│   
│   @henrywfisher comes to mind. I see Henry as an honorary team member. He did a *lot of the work* on the UI.
│   
│   (This is how it looked originally. So you know how much he did.) https://t.co/41yI3R9E6n
│   Images:
│     - [Image #0] The image is a screenshot of a Twitter page with a tweet composition window open, overlaid on top of a darkened Twitter feed. 
│       
│       To recreate this image, start by creating a dark gray background representing a Twitter feed. On the left side, include a profile picture and username "@nosilverv" with the text "NotRivalVoices" below it, along with some statistics. 
│       
│       In the center, overlay a "Compose new Tweet" window with a cursor at the end of the text "keyword keyword keyword keyword." The window should have various icons for media, GIFs, and location, as well as a "Tweet" button. 
│       
│       To the right of the composition window, include a cartoon paperclip with eyes and a speech bubble saying, "Hi My algo says that these tweets of yours might be related to the one you're composing! Let me know if this is right!" 
│       
│       Below the paperclip, display three tweets from the same user, "@nosilverv," with different content and engagement metrics. 
│       
│       Finally, include a large, darkened image of a person wearing a leather jacket and sunglasses, positioned below the composition window.
│   ↓
│   1321518953836040193 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 15
│   @garybasin who provided me with the initial push to get this project going and without whom it wouldn't have started.
│   ↓
│   1321518955312435201 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 9
│   Miguel Morel, @fiddlemath, and @nnevvinn without whose  experienced entrepreneurs lessons we couldn't have made it this far.
│   ↓
│   1321518956633612291 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 29 💬 2
│   Of course, @visakanv and @0x49fa98. They provided the original inspiration for ThreadHelper with their threads. The original project codename  was “visa-as-a-service”, because I wanted to thread just as well as them without actually having to put in the manual (threading) work.
│   ↓
│   1321518958101618689 [2020-10-28] @nosilverv 💜 20
